prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for taking my bonus and creating a "secret" room in my house (complete with a bookshelf door)?
Hello AITA. Thank you for taking the time to weigh in on what was supposed to be a fun project but has turned into a major issue between my fiancé and I. I am a moderator on several other subs so I am using a throwaway so as to not cross the streams so to speak. 

Last year, after several years of being out of steady work, I was able to land a really good job. My new company had an unreasonably good year and in late February I got a five figure bonus. I have always wanted a "secret" room in my house, I honestly don't know why but it's just always seemed so cool to have a room where I pull a lever, a bookcase opens to my private space. I figured with the bonus the time was right so I hired a good contractor, they tore down some walls and started digging up the foundation to our spare bedroom since the secret room will have a circular staircase to a new basement. The house was my grandma's and was given to me paid off when she died so I own the house outright and have full legal authority to do this. 

Fiance is so furious at me she's thinking about calling off the wedding. She says that taking my bonus was wildly irresponsible and that we could have used the money to pay off debt, pay for some of the wedding to take pressure of her parents or even save. I counter with this bonus was essentially "found" money that may never happen again so we might have fun with it while we have it. She says that we are getting married, this has to be a discussion and me digging up the foundation and tearing out several walls in the house has made it impossible for her to live in the house. I counter again that its my house. The argument has gotten so intense that she has moved in with her sister and we may be looking at the end of our 2 year relationship. 

Am I the asshole in this situation?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the AITA post is in the wrong. The situation involves using a bonus to create a secret room in their house, which is causing a major conflict with their fiancé.

First, I need to consider the key points. The author got a five-figure bonus from a job they just landed after being out of steady work. They used this bonus to build a secret room, which involves significant construction. The house is owned outright by the author, as it was given by their grandma. The fiancé is upset, thinking the money should have been used for shared goals like paying debt, wedding costs, or saving. She's so upset she moved out and considering ending the engagement.

Now, I need to assess whether the author is in the wrong. Legally, since the author owns the house, they have the right to modify it. The bonus is their income, and they might see it as "found money" from a good year at work. However, relationships involve shared decision-making. Even though the house is the author's, a fiancé might expect discussions about major projects that affect both partners, especially when significant money is involved. The construction is causing the fiancé to not be able to live in the house, which is a big deal. The fact that this is leading to the engagement being called off suggests the decision had a major impact without considering the partner's feelings and needs.

Financial responsibility is also a factor. The author chose to spend a bonus on a personal project instead of shared financial goals. While the bonus is a one-time windfall, the fiancé argues it could have been used more responsibly. The author's stance that it's their house and their money might overlook the collaborative nature of a committed relationship, especially when planning to marry.

So, the question is about balance between personal desires and shared responsibilities. The author's actions, while legally justified, may ignore the emotional and relational aspects. The fiancé's perspective is valid because major financial decisions in a relationship should involve mutual agreement. The secret room project's impact on their living situation and the wedding plans adds to the severity of the issue. Therefore, the author might be in the wrong for not discussing the plan with their fiancé and prioritizing a personal project over shared goals, leading to significant relationship strain.
